events.name: World War II
events.blurb: A global conflict that reshaped the political and social landscape of the 20th century.

details.imageCaption: The aftermath of the atomic bombing of Nagasaki.

causes.title: Treaty of Versailles (1919)
causes.text: Harsh penalties on Germany after WWI, including territorial loss and reparations, fueled resentment and nationalism.

causes.title: Rise of Totalitarian Regimes
causes.text: Fascist leaders like Adolf Hitler (Germany), Benito Mussolini (Italy), and Emperor Hirohito (Japan) pursued aggressive expansionist policies.

causes.title: Expansionism & Appeasement
causes.text: Axis powers expanded into neighbouring countries while the Allied powers, especially Britain and France, initially followed a policy of appeasement.

causes.title: Failure of the League of Nations
causes.text: The international body failed to prevent aggression by the Axis powers.

causes.title: The Great Depression
causes.text: Global economic hardship allowed extremist ideologies to gain support.

major-events.title: Invasion of Poland
major-events.text: Germany invaded Poland, prompting Britain and France to declare war on Germany two days later.

major-events.title: Fall of France
major-events.text: Germany quickly conquered France using blitzkrieg tactics. France was divided into German-occupied and Vichy-controlled regions.

major-events.title: Battle of Britain
major-events.text: The UK successfully resisted Germany's aerial bombing campaign, halting Hitler's plan to invade Britain.

major-events.title: Operation Barbarossa
major-events.text: Germany's invasion of the Soviet Union marked a major turning point. The harsh winter and Soviet resistance stalled German advances.

major-events.title: Pearl Harbor Attack
major-events.text: Japan attacked the US naval base in Hawaii, prompting the US to join the war.

major-events.title: Battle of Stalingrad
major-events.text: A turning point on the Eastern Front, where the Soviet Union decisively defeated Germany.

major-events.title: D-Day
major-events.text: Allied forces landed in Normandy, France, beginning the liberation of Western Europe from Nazi control.

major-events.title: Fall of Berlin & Hitler's Death
major-events.text: Soviet forces captured Berlin. Hitler committed suicide, and Germany surrendered on May 7, 1945.

major-events.title: Atomic Bombings
major-events.text: The US dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, forcing Japan to surrender on Sep 2, 1945.

key-participants.name: Adolf Hitler
key-participants.role: Dictator of Nazi Germany, orchestrated the Holocaust and led military expansion across Europe.

key-participants.name: Winston Churchill
key-participants.role: Prime Minister who led Britain through the war with powerful speeches and resolve.

key-participants.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt
key-participants.role: U.S. President during most of the war; declared war after Pearl Harbor.

key-participants.name: Joseph Stalin
key-participants.role: Soviet leader; led USSR through brutal Eastern Front campaigns against Nazi Germany.

key-participants.name: Benito Mussolini
key-participants.role: Fascist dictator who allied with Hitler; was eventually overthrown and executed.

key-participants.name: Emperor Hirohito
key-participants.role: Monarch during Japan's imperial expansion and wartime actions.

key-participants.name: Dwight D. Eisenhower
key-participants.role: Supreme Allied Commander in Europe; led the D-Day invasion.

key-participants.name: Harry S. Truman
key-participants.role: U.S. President who decided to use atomic bombs on Japan.

outcomes.title: Defeat and Division of Germany
outcomes.text: Germany was defeated and divided into East (Soviet) and West (Allied).

outcomes.title: Surrender and Occupation of Japan
outcomes.text: Japan surrendered, leading to U.S. occupation and democratization.

outcomes.title: Establishment of the United Nations
outcomes.text: The United Nations was established to promote peace and international cooperation.

outcomes.title: Beginning of the Cold War
outcomes.text: The Cold War began between the U.S. and the USSR.

outcomes.title: Decolonization Accelerated
outcomes.text: Decolonization accelerated in Asia and Africa.

outcomes.title: Casualties and Human Cost
outcomes.text: Over 70 million died, including military and civilian casualties.

outcomes.title: The Holocaust
outcomes.text: The Holocaust revealed, resulting in global condemnation and human rights reforms.

events.name: French Revolution
events.blurb: A period of radical social and political upheaval in France.
events.description: A period of radical social and political upheaval in France that had a major impact on France and throughout Europe.

causes.title: Social Inequality
causes.text: The population was divided into three estates: the clergy (First Estate), the nobility (Second Estate), and the commoners (Third Estate). The Third Estate, despite outnumbering the aristocrats, possessed little political power and could be outvoted by the other two estates.

causes.title: Economic Instability
causes.text: The country faced severe financial problems due to wars, poor harvests, and the monarchy's spending. The price of bread soared, leading to widespread hunger and discontent.

causes.title: Enlightenment Ideology
causes.text: Philosophers like Rousseau and Voltaire inspired calls for democracy, liberty, and equality.

major-events.title: Estates-General
major-events.text: King Louis XVI called an assembly to address the country's financial crisis, but it ultimately failed to resolve the tension between the estates.

major-events.title: National Assembly
major-events.text: Due to tensions from the Estates-General, the Third Estate declared itself the National Assembly, pledging not to disperse until they gave France a new constitution.

major-events.title: Storming of the Bastille
major-events.text: Angry Parisians stormed the Bastille fortress, a symbol of royal tyranny. The King yielded to this, recognizing the sovereignty of his people, marking the start of the revolution.

major-events.title: Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen
major-events.text: Document expressing principles of liberty, equality, and fraternity, inspired by Enlightenment ideologies.

major-events.title: Women's March on Versailles
major-events.text: Concerned over the high price of bread, thousands of women rioted and marched to Versailles, forcing the royals to return to Paris with them.

major-events.title: Execution of Louis XVI
major-events.text: Marked the end of the monarchy and the establishment of the First French Republic. Louis XVI was executed by the guillotine for treason, exhibiting the revolution's radical turn. His execution shocked Europe and increased tensions across other monarchies.

major-events.title: Reign of Terror
major-events.text: Led by Robespierre, this period saw mass executions of enemies of the revolution, including King Louis XVI and Queen Marie Antoinette. Resulted in the deaths of thousands, including revolutionaries, and created an atmosphere of fear.

major-events.title: Fall of Robespierre
major-events.text: Maximilien Robespierre was arrested and executed by his political rivals. This marked the end of the Reign of Terror and ushered in a more moderate phase of the revolution. The execution represented a rejection of radicalism, and France's stability rose.

major-events.title: Rise of Napoleon Bonaparte
major-events.text: Napoleon staged and seized power in a coup d'état, ending the revolutionary government and establishing himself as leader. France transitioned from revolutionary ideals to authoritarian rule.

key-participants.name: King Louis XVI
key-participants.role: The monarch whose weak leadership and financial mismanagement contributed to the revolution's outbreak.

key-participants.name: Marie Antoinette
key-participants.role: The queen, unpopular for her perceived extravagance during times of poverty and financial instability.

key-participants.name: Maximilien Robespierre
key-participants.role: Radical leader during the Reign of Terror, eventually executed himself.

key-participants.name: Napoleon Bonaparte
key-participants.role: Military general who seized power through a coup d'état and later became emperor.

outcomes.title: End of Monarchy
outcomes.text: The revolution abolished the monarchy and established a republic; however, it was later replaced by Napoleon's rule.

outcomes.title: Social Class Changes
outcomes.text: The revolution dismantled the traditional class system as the privileges of the nobility and clergy were abolished. Common people gained more rights and opportunities.

outcomes.title: Spread of Revolutionary Ideals
outcomes.text: The revolution inspired movements for democracy and equality across Europe and the rest of the world.

outcomes.title: Reforms
outcomes.text: New laws promoted civil equality, freedom of religion, and the end of slavery in French colonies.
